citations.narrative:
An enclosure housing goats, sheep, and a llama does not have an effective barrier to prevent contact between the
animals and members of the public. A food dispenser is located nearby. Members of the public can purchase food and
feed the animals by reaching over the fence surrounding the enclosure. There is no attendant consistently present in the
area during times of public contact, although an area employee walks by at least 3 times per day.
Sufficient barriers are important to prevent unauthorized contact between animals and members of the public. Animals
that may come into contact with members of the public in an unsupervised setting may cause- or may receive injuries.
Correct by 8/1/23 by ensuring that enclosures have sufficient distance and /or barriers between the animals on display
and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of animals and the public. Additionally, public contact with animals
must be supervised by a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee/attendant at all times during
periods of public contact in accordance with 2.131(d)(2).

An enclosure housing 2 adult common marmosets does not have an effective public barrier. The outdoor part of the
enclosure is enclosed in wire mesh with small (approximately 0.5 inch) openings. A member of the public was observed
touching the wire mesh and sticking their fingers through it, while the animals were very close by. There is no attendant
stationed in the area and the enclosure is not intended to allow animal contact by the public.
Monkeys that come into contact with members of the public may cause injuries to humans such as bites or scratches, or
the animals may become injured themselves. Humans can harbor germs that are harmful to monkeys.
Correct by 8/12/23 by ensuring that enclosures for nonhuman primates have an effective public barrier which restricts
physical contact between the nonhuman primates and the public.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
An enclosure housing goats, sheep, and a llama does not have an effective barrier to prevent contact between the 
animals and members of the public. A food dispenser is located nearby. Members of the public can purchase food and 
feed the animals by reaching over the fence surrounding the enclosure. There is no attendant consistently present in the 
area during times of public contact, although an area employee walks by at least 3 times per day.  
Sufficient barriers are important to prevent unauthorized contact between animals and members of the public. Animals 
that may come into contact with members of the public in an unsupervised setting may cause- or may receive injuries.  
Correct by 8/1/23 by ensuring that enclosures have sufficient distance and /or barriers between the animals on display 
and the general viewing public as to assure the safety of animals and the public. Additionally, public contact with animals 
must be supervised by a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee/attendant at all times during 
periods of public contact in accordance with 2.131(d)(2). 
3.77(g) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
An enclosure housing 2 adult common marmosets does not have an effective public barrier. The outdoor part of the 
enclosure is enclosed in wire mesh with small (approximately 0.5 inch) openings. A member of the public was observed 
touching the wire mesh and sticking their fingers through it, while the animals were very close by. There is no attendant 
stationed in the area and the enclosure is not intended to allow animal contact by the public. 
Monkeys that come into contact with members of the public may cause injuries to humans such as bites or scratches, or 
the animals may become injured themselves. Humans can harbor germs that are harmful to monkeys.  
Correct by 8/12/23 by ensuring that enclosures for nonhuman primates have an effective public barrier which restricts 
physical contact between the nonhuman primates and the public. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
